Literature Review: The econometrics of nonlinear budget sets has emerged as a critical area of research in understanding consumer behavior and decision-making processes under complex budget constraints. This literature review delves into the development of nonparametric models and methods for estimating choice models with nonlinear budget sets, focusing on the budget set regression and its implications for empirical research. The exploration of utility maximization within a nonparametric framework, the role of kink probabilities, and the application of instrumental variable estimation are also discussed, highlighting the advancements and challenges in this field. The concept of budget set regression, which refers to the conditional expectation of a choice variable given the budget set, has been pivotal in addressing the curse of dimensionality inherent in nonparametric models with general heterogeneity. This approach has been shown to yield empirical results that diverge from those obtained through maximum likelihood estimation, offering more informative inference (Blomquist & Newey, 2002). The utility maximization hypothesis, when applied within a nonparametric model, significantly reduces the dimensionality problem by leveraging the structure imposed by the budget set, thereby facilitating more accurate estimation of consumer preferences (Hausman & Newey, 2016). Kink probabilities, which represent the likelihood of consumers choosing at the kinks of the budget set, provide valuable information for identifying nonparametric utility functions with general heterogeneity. These probabilities have been instrumental in uncovering the underlying preferences and constraints faced by individuals, offering insights into the behavioral responses to nonlinear budget sets (Saez, 2010). The application of instrumental variable (IV) estimation in this context has further enriched the understanding of heterogeneity in preferences. IV methods have been employed to address endogeneity issues and to provide evidence of the diverse preferences across different segments of the population, thereby enhancing the robustness of the empirical findings (Heckman & Vytlacil, 2007). The integration of these methodologies has led to significant advancements in the econometric analysis of nonlinear budget sets. However, challenges remain, particularly in the accurate specification of the utility function and the identification of valid instruments for IV estimation. Future research directions may include the exploration of more flexible utility specifications, the development of novel identification strategies, and the application of these methods to a broader range of economic contexts. In conclusion, the econometrics of nonlinear budget sets has made substantial progress in understanding consumer behavior under complex constraints. The development of nonparametric models, the application of budget set regression, and the use of kink probabilities and instrumental variable estimation have collectively contributed to a deeper understanding of the heterogeneity in preferences and the implications for policy analysis. As the field continues to evolve, it holds the promise of providing even more nuanced insights into the economic decision-making process.
